item.description:
During the Month of February the CMF will focus on Educational Events, specifically Human Evolutionary History and related topics. The Harvard Museum of Natural History has an exciting series of lectures and classes that address these subjects. After all, the more we know about ourselves and our planet, the richer our lives will be.

Important note: This event is by pre-registration through the HMNH only.

Exploring Biodiversity - In this class, David Blackburn will focus on how patterns of biodiversity are documented and interpreted, and ask questions such as "what is a species?", "how do species form?", and "how do we determine their relationship to one another?". By examining the vast diversity of groups such as vertebrates and arthropods, we'll discuss the ways that these groups have evolved remarkable adaptations for new and changing environments. Lastly, we will explore what has caused both past and present extinctions, and how current biodiversity research and exploration plays a critical role in conserving biodiversity.

Instructor: David Blackburn; Graduate Student, Department of Herpetology, Harvard University
item.name: Exploring Biodiversity
